title: HIV and Your Job

content: Many experiences with HIV can feel consuming. Because this disease is life-altering, it can be difficult to manage every area of your life that’s impacted. When it comes to your work life, risks can be high.
There’s a mountain of challenges to overcome. So, when you’re trying to accept your diagnosis and adapt, how it’ll impact your career may be at the top of your concerns.

Although HIV/AIDS has been around for 40+ years, there’s still stigma, misinformation and judgment. The likelihood of discrimination, especially in the workplace, is higher for you than for those who don’t have HIV.

Be extra cautious in navigating situations involving disclosure of your status at work, even to your colleagues. Depending on your career field, you need to gauge how safe (if at all) it is to reveal your status.

When I learned I was HIV positive in 2004, I was working in the non-profit arts sector at multiple performing arts venues. Ironically, on the day I learned my HIV status, I was supposed to be starting a new job as assistant theater box office manager. Even with all I was going through, I was fortunate to avoid concerns about how HIV would impact my job.

content: I was still private about my situation. But I didn’t fear I’d lose my job. That’s because, in most cases, there’s more open-mindedness in the world of arts and theater.

I had it much easier than some others in that regard. But I still experienced plenty of stressors as a result of being newly diagnosed, while also taking on a position in management. It was demanding and time consuming. Having worked in box office management and ticketing for about five years by then, I was no stranger to the high stress.

I recall feeling relieved to have work responsibilities to keep me busy, and to prevent me from being worried and afraid about being HIV-positive. I was still pursuing artistic endeavors by auditioning and working as an actor. While I was stumbling my way through living with HIV, I had to find a way to do my job while also trying to take better care of myself. None of this was easy.

content: I can’t tell you I had a magic formula or hack to make it through, because it was all trial and error. I discovered the importance of balancing and prioritizing what really mattered, and surrendering the rest. During those early years, I developed valuable practices and skills to manage the life, work, and artistic responsibilities on my plate.
Regardless of your job or profession, life with HIV impacts you. But it doesn’t have to uproot your life, or put your life at risk. This looks different for each person.

Across the board, there’ll be change and adaptation. That means taking medication and figuring out how it factors into your everyday life. It may mean making adjustments to your work schedule or overall routine, so that you have adequate rest. That’s always important, as it pertains to your overall health and well-being.

In more common ways, which apply to everyone regardless of HIV status, changes may involve modifying your work schedule and lightening your workload, when possible. That can help you lessen or avoid stress, which is so important when you live with HIV.

content: Above all, create a viable work/life balance as much as possible. Prioritize your health and wellbeing above your job or career. Learning to manage your life and your job, and take care of yourself, is a tall but possible order.
